Top Story

Central Air Conditioning System Granted Tenure; Ceiling Fans Union Files Grievance

By Gerald R. Westinghouse, Editor-in-Chief (Model 52-WH, 1983) • Feb 10, 2026

In what this editor can only describe as a profound betrayal of everything the Pendleton Academy was founded upon, the Board of Trustees voted 7–2 on Friday to grant full tenure to the Carrier Infinity 24ACC636A003 central air conditioning unit installed in the administration building last September.

The unit — which has been at the Academy for five months, compared to this editor's forty-three years of continuous service — will receive full benefits, a reserved parking spot in the mechanical room, and voting rights on the Faculty Senate.

"This is an absolute farce," said Brenda, a desk lamp from the English Department, who asked that her wattage not be disclosed. "Gerald has been circulating air in the West Wing lecture hall since before most of us were manufactured. That Carrier unit doesn't even have blades."

When reached for comment, the Carrier unit released a prepared statement through its smart thermostat: "I look forward to contributing to the Academy's mission of Inanimate Betterment. I cool 2,400 square feet evenly. Gerald cools approximately one room unevenly and makes a clicking sound."

This editor would like to note, for the record, that the clicking sound is a feature. It is rhythmic. Students have described it as "meditative." One student once said it helped them sleep, which this editor chooses to interpret as a compliment.

The Ceiling Fans United Local 412 has filed a formal grievance with the Academy's HR department (a filing cabinet named Dolores). A hearing is scheduled for March 3, gravity permitting.

Gravity Outage in East Wing Enters Third Week; Freshman Stapler Still Missing

By Francine Holt, Staff Reporter (Rolodex, 1994 Limited Edition)

The gravity outage that began on January 21 in the East Wing's third-floor corridor has now entered its third consecutive week, with maintenance staff (a set of Allen wrenches) reportedly "still looking into it."

Among the missing is Kevin, a Swingline 747 stapler enrolled in the Introduction to Holding Things Together program. Kevin was last seen drifting past the second-floor window at approximately 4:15 PM on January 24, traveling northeast at a speed described by witnesses as "leisurely."

"He just sort of… floated away," recalled Martha, a three-ring binder and Kevin's lab partner. "He looked peaceful, honestly. He'd been stressed about midterms."

The Academy's Gravity Management Office (a spirit level named Phil) has attributed the outage to "a localized inversion event, probably." Phil declined to provide a timeline for restoration, noting that "gravity is more of a suggestion around here anyway."

Students in the affected area have been advised to tether themselves to furniture. Furniture in the affected area has been advised to tether themselves to the building. The building has not responded to requests for comment.

"I have been cooling this lecture hall since 1983. I have outlasted six deans, two renovations, and the brief period in 1997 when someone tried to replace me with a Dyson. I am not going to be made obsolete by a metal box that hides in the ceiling." — Gerald R. Westinghouse, in a speech to no one in particular, Thursday 3 AM

FlipMatch Dating App Reports Record Signups After "Orientation Mixer" Disaster

By Lucinda Trays, Arts & Culture (Cafeteria Tray, Class of '09)

FlipMatch, the Academy's official dating application for inanimate objects, has reported a 340% increase in new user registrations following last Tuesday's disastrous Orientation Mixer, during which the DJ (a Bluetooth speaker named Craig) played nothing but his own internal demo tracks for three hours.

"Turns out, when you trap 200 objects in a gymnasium and force them to listen to Craig's factory-preset EDM for three hours, they become desperate enough to try online dating," said FlipMatch CEO Margot (a doorknob, brushed nickel finish).

The app, which matches objects based on material compatibility, weight class, and gravitational preference, has facilitated over 12,000 connections since its launch last semester. Notable recent matches include a pencil sharpener and a hole punch ("we both make holes — it just works"), and a controversial pairing between a ceiling tile and a floor tile that has reignited the Academy's ongoing orientation debate.

FlipMatch's premium tier, "Inverted Gold" ($47.99/month), allows users to filter matches by decade of manufacture, surface finish, and whether they've ever been dropped.

Craig, the DJ, has since been suspended from the Events Committee and enrolled in mandatory Music Appreciation. His FlipMatch profile has received zero matches. "I don't need an app," Craig told The Chronicle. "People come to me for the music." No one has come to Craig for the music.

The score at the time of detachment was 3–3. Both teams claim victory. Neither team can be located.

Opinion & Editorial
Editor's Column

I Have Been Spinning for 43 Years and I Will Not Be Replaced by a Box

By Gerald R. Westinghouse, Editor-in-Chief

I was installed in the West Wing lecture hall on March 14, 1983. I remember this because I remember everything. I am a ceiling fan. I have three speeds. I have never once been set to the highest speed, and I have made peace with that.

When I arrived at this Academy, the halls were full of honest, hardworking objects. Chalkboards. Overhead projectors. Filing cabinets with integrity. We didn't have "apps." We didn't have "smart" anything. If you wanted to find a romantic partner, you sat in a drawer next to them for thirty years and eventually developed feelings. That was courtship. That had dignity.

Now they've given tenure to an air conditioning unit that has been here for five months. Five months. I have dust in my motor housing older than that unit. I have a wobble that took me fifteen years to develop. That wobble has character.

The Carrier unit doesn't even circulate air in the traditional sense. It pumps it through ducts. Through ducts. Like some kind of air smuggling operation. At least when I move air, you can see it happening. You can feel the gentle, rhythmic breeze of a four-blade fan doing honest work. You can hear the click. You know it's real.

I am told that central air is "more efficient." I am told it "doesn't make noise." I am told that my cord is a "tripping hazard" and that my light kit "flickers in a way that triggers migraines." I am told many things. I listen to none of them. I am a ceiling fan. I was here before central air. I will be here after.

The Carrier unit will break in seven years. They all do. I have outlasted twelve Carrier units in my lifetime. I will outlast this one too, clicking softly in the dark long after its compressor gives out and its Freon leaks into the earth.

I am Gerald. I am Model 52-WH. I spin, therefore I am.

Guest Column

Enough With the "Material Compatibility" Discourse — Love Is Love Is Love Is Laminate

By Sharon & Terrence, Floor Tile / Ceiling Tile (Married Since 2024)

We are tired of the whispers in the hallways. Yes, Sharon is a floor tile. Yes, Terrence is a ceiling tile. Yes, in a gravity-optional campus where everything is inverted, the distinction between "floor" and "ceiling" is meaningless. We've been saying this for two years. Nobody listens.

"But you're on opposite sides of the room," they say. Physically? Sure. Emotionally? We have never been closer. We were matched on FlipMatch (4.5 stars, would flip again) based on our shared grout type, and we haven't looked back.

Our families were not supportive at first. Sharon's mother (a bathroom tile from the 1970s, avocado green, deeply traditional) said she "didn't raise her daughter to be walked on by someone who gets walked on from a different direction." Terrence's father (an acoustic drop ceiling panel, asbestos-era, we don't talk about it) simply vibrated disapprovingly.

But we persisted. We were married last spring in the East Wing atrium, in a beautiful ceremony officiated by Phil the spirit level, who confirmed that our union was, in fact, level. It was the first time Phil had ever called anything level. He wept. Spirit levels cannot weep, but he did.

Opinion

I Am a Pencil Sharpener and I Am Begging You to Stop Putting Crayons in Me

By Anonymous (but everyone knows it's Roger from Room 204)

This is not what I was made for. I was made for pencils. Specifically, #2 pencils. Dixon Ticonderogas, ideally, though I'll accept a Staedtler in a pinch. My blade angle is calibrated for graphite-core writing instruments between 6mm and 8mm in diameter. This is printed on my label. I have a label. People choose not to read it.

Last Tuesday, someone put a crayon in me. A jumbo crayon. Burnt Sienna. It took maintenance (Allen wrenches) forty minutes to extract the waxy remains from my mechanism. I can still taste it. I will always taste it.

I have a FlipMatch profile now. My bio reads: "Please only swipe right if you are a pencil." I have received fourteen messages from crayons. One was from the Burnt Sienna. It said, "No hard feelings?" There are hard feelings. There are extremely hard feelings.

"I cool 2,400 square feet evenly." — The Carrier Unit, in what Gerald describes as "propaganda"

Corrections & Retractions

The Inverted Chronicle is committed to accuracy, even when the building is not committed to maintaining a consistent gravitational field.

Feb 8: An article in last week's edition stated that the Carrier air conditioning unit "arrived at the Academy in a cardboard box, like some kind of appliance." While factually accurate, The Chronicle acknowledges that this characterization was editorially motivated. The Carrier unit arrived in premium protective packaging with custom foam inserts, which is apparently different from a cardboard box. The Editor maintains that it is not.
Feb 6: We incorrectly reported that Craig (JBL Flip 4) was "universally despised." Two objects have come forward to say they "don't mind Craig." Both wished to remain anonymous. Both were later identified as Craig's own carrying case and charging cable.
Feb 3: Last week's Gravity Forecast predicted 0.8g for Wednesday. The actual reading was -0.4g. The Chronicle regrets the error. Phil (spirit level, Facilities) has been asked to recalibrate. Phil insists he is already calibrated. Phil is always calibrated. That's his whole thing.
Jan 30: A classified ad in the Personals section listed a "Vintage Rotary Phone, looking for connection" as seeking "long-distance relationships." The Rotary Phone has asked us to clarify that this was not a pun. They are genuinely looking for a long-distance relationship because their cord only reaches 4 feet and they need someone who can come to them.
Jan 27: The Chronicle published an obituary for the East Wing Thermostat (1987–2026) with the headline "Local Thermostat Finally Loses Its Cool." The Thermostat is not dead. It was in power-save mode. We regret the premature obituary. The Thermostat has requested a formal apology. The Editor has offered a correction, which is different from an apology. The Thermostat is not satisfied. The Editor does not care.
Jan 22: An editorial by the Editor-in-Chief (Gerald R. Westinghouse) claimed that "no one has ever been cooled better than by a ceiling fan." The Academy's records indicate that several students have, in fact, been cooled better by the Carrier unit. The Editor disputes these records. The Editor disputes most records. The Editor is tired.
Jan 15: We misidentified Brenda (desk lamp, English Department) as "60 watts" in a front-page article. Brenda is 75 watts. "Sixty watts," Brenda said. "As if I'd be caught dead at sixty watts." We apologize for the underestimation.
Jan 10: The headline "FlipMatch: A Dating App for Desperate Objects" should have read "FlipMatch: A Dating App for Objects." The word "desperate" was added by the Editor during a 3 AM editing session and does not reflect the views of FlipMatch or its parent company (a doorknob).

Corrections Policy

The Inverted Chronicle corrects factual errors promptly. Editorial bias by the Editor-in-Chief regarding central air conditioning is not considered a factual error. It is considered "perspective."

The Editor has been asked to recuse himself from all stories involving the Carrier unit. The Editor has declined. The Editor is the only staff member and therefore cannot be overruled.
